The DhÄraá¹‡Ä« SÅ«tra of the Most Excellent Lamp King in the East. This sÅ«tra in the Tang canon is called the SÅ«tra of the TathÄgata Most Excellent Lamp King in the East.
The text and meaning are mostly the same as the Song canon, but there is more.
According to the Kaiyuan Catalog,
it says there were four translations, three preserved and one lost.
The lost translation of the Eastern Jin is
called the DhÄraá¹‡Ä« Chapter SÅ«tra.
Some versions do not have the character chapter, which is the third translation but one version is missing.
This translation by Yijing.
The text and meaning of the Song and Tang canons are very different, and the titles also differ slightly.
It is unknown which is correct.
The Song canon version is ancient and straightforward,
it does not seem to be Yijing's translation.
Moreover, the text frequently says DhÄraá¹‡Ä« phrases.
It is feared that this sÅ«tra is the lost DhÄraá¹‡Ä« Phrases SÅ«tra.
The Song canon lost Yijing's translation but obtained the lost DhÄraá¹‡Ä« SÅ«tra of the Eastern Jin.
It is seen in the sÅ«tra that there is mention of the Most Excellent Lamp King.
Thus, it became what Yijing translated as the Lamp King Sutra.
If not, why would there be a translation by one person,
with different titles and contents,
and different texts in detail and brevity?
Now, by preserving both, the four translations are complete.
